Award.AwardTitle: REU: Undergraduate Research in Estuarine and Coastal Marine Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program is located at the Duke University Marine Laboratory (DUML), Piver's Island, NC. The award supports a three-year program that will provide eight student internships each summer for a 10-week research experience at DUML. The PI will recruit students nationally and at Elizabeth City State, Savannah State University (SSU) and the 34 schools (mainly non-PhD granting institutions) that are affiliated with the Marine Laboratory in the Marine Sciences Educational Consortium. Students will live in Marine Laboratory dormitories and take their meals in the dining hall. Students will have a choice of ten advisors in the general research areas of (1) sensory physiology and behavior, (2) environmental toxicology, (3) molecular biology and genetics, and (4) coastal and estuarine processes. Co-curricular activities include a Marine Laboratory-sponsored seminar program, participation in selected field trips and water related recreational activities. At the end of the summer, REU students present their results during a student research symposium, and they prepare a scientific manuscript on their research. Support provided by NSF includes funding for student stipends, student travel to and from the site, student housing and meals and some administrative costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The four objectives of the Duke University Marine Laboratory REU program include:

1)     Development of a peer-group environment, in which students work independently on a focused research project.

2)     Training of students in basic research, communication skills in scientific writing and poster formats, and scientific ethics.

3)     Engagement of students in a mentored research process from conception of an original research question to project design, implementation, analysis, and communication.

4)     Informing students about scientific career paths, especially in ocean sciences.

            Target students were minorities who were majoring in science, and who were rising sophomores, juniors and seniors.  To this end, the Marine Laboratory partnered with the School of Mathematics, Science, and Technology at Elizabeth City State University (ECSU) and Savannah State University (SSU). Additional recruiting occurred through web-based advertising and from the 34 schools that are affiliated with the Marine Laboratory in the Marine Sciences Educational Consortium. We received 843 applications and selected 24 students (8 each summer) to participate in the program. The percentage of minority participants was 42% (11/24), and the percentage of students from colleges/universities lacking a Ph.D. program was 38% (9/24).  Students completed a research project, presented 3 oral reports on their projects and wrote papers in the form of a scientific manuscript on their project.  They attended sessions on poster and graphic presentation, manuscript preparation, and careers in science. Ten papers were published in the peer reviewed scientific journals and 12 presentations were made at scientific meetings.
